title: A tour of the Pascal Challenge programme

author: Michèle Sebag, Laboratoire de Recherche en Informatique (LRI), National Center for Scientific Research (CNRS)

segmentation: OK, so.
I propose that we start this morning about the challenge program in Pascal.
Welcome to everybody.
So pleasure to be to be here.
I will be.
I will be discussing what the the challenge.
Ages have been.

And basically this is a I try to summarize in this first talk what we did and what we feel where the good points the not so good points and basically the I think that the men are the main point is getting your feedback about what you what you think and how to improve the challenges.
So.
Why, what and what was the goal and the motivations and and everything and how we can change and then add new things and then improve the old things?
And also what we know now that we can't expect from challenges, OK?

The most famous is of obviously the DARPA challenge.

To do things.
There is the fact that we want to push the state of the art to know where the frontier is and to push it a bit further.

And to raise the standards, because once you've participated into a challenge, then there is a lot of mistakes that you don't do anymore about how to validate your algorithm and how to deliver proper, say, assessment of what it's able to do.
There is also the fact that it's it's fun.
OK, I think that we should put it blankly.
It's it's a good way to attract people to offer an attractive face to the computer world.
OK, and um.
And also when you have many people from from different fields then there is at first there is always a first blockage because people don't have the same words to speak about the same things.
And of course if you ground the concepts on the challenge then it's much easier to have this cross language step down.
OK, so well, I wouldn't.
I wouldn't like to appear to be bragging, but I feel that of course I should have said much earlier that of course in challenges to collective enterprise of course.
I'm in the only here to report on this, but the work has been done by by the others basically so well my feeling.

OK, we said, OK, we said the motor was a catalyst for research and for application development.
OK, and there is also the fact that we wanted to.

OK we we were.

We were.

I mean every challenge organizer to come and and give an account of what had been done in the challenge.
The point is.
That as we had something like 20 challenges, I felt at some point that it was not possible to to have such a sample.
OK, which is why I undersampled.
And of course you turned in the end that some people couldn't come.
And and I did not reconsider the thing.
So I would like to apologize for this.
But as you can see, the if you remember our first goal and then the the title of the of the FP call was.

Text and web and this session.

Questions in the exploratory challenges are about the the new frontiers of the of the ML field.

It's researchers, but in 2005 it was not so, so I could say that.

OK?

OK. And so the message through the challenges is that you can come.
And so I feel this is a very good message too.
So the legacy is that we will have hopefully not awfully.

Going further.

The results of the of the challenges as much as we could have and and everything is ready for us.

How the various algorithm did OK, so that way you might consider that definitely all examples are equal in general in the score, but they are not that equal.

A free tickets to the machine learning summer schools might be also.
Good thing.
